utterances: In Ankara tonight, Erdogan addressed a cheering crowd outside his party headquarters.
(Turkish spoken)
(Turkish spoken)
I'm joined now by NPR's Ivan Watson in Istanbul.
Ivan, what was Erdogan's message to the crowd?
Well, he called this a victory for democracy, Jacki.
He said that Turkey would continue on its path towards economic and political reforms.
He was magnanimous to his opponent.
This campaign period had gotten very dirty, a lot of smearing and insults being hurled back and forth.
He called for unity now.
And an important note, he said he would remain committed to Turkey's secular democracy.
So the Islamic moderates are still in power.
Is this a defeat for Turkish secularists?
Yes, to some degree.
That's how it's being interpreted here.
And perhaps also for the military, which spoke out against Erdogan's candidate for president two months ago that touched off a crisis, which led to these early elections, which we just had today.
The secularists, they ran on a platform that basically accused Erdogan of being an Islamist.
And they accused him of trying to transform Turkey's very strict secular system of government.
This is an overwhelmingly Muslim country.
And they did not really win more votes on this platform.
What were the other headlines from today's election?
Well, we have some new additions to the Turkish parliament.
The right-wing nationalists have gotten in.
There's been a nationalist backlash, in part, to Erdogan's bid to become the first Muslim country to join the European Union.
And at the same time, we've seen Kurdish nationalists from the oppressed Kurdish minority.
They've actually gotten back into the parliament for the first time in more than a decade since Kurdish lawmakers were arrested for speaking Kurdish in public.

So we are likely to have quite a broad political spectrum now in that national assembly and definitely some political enemies that are going to have to sit at least glaring at each other from across the aisles of the assembly room.
Well, speaking of that, very quickly, Ivan.
The election was held because the prime minister wanted to appoint another Islamist as president.
But the seculars and the army protested.
If it's still the parliament that appoints the president, then Erdogan's party is still in power.
Isn't that still square one?
Exactly.
Erdogan has won a majority in parliament, but he doesn't have enough seats in that body to elect a president on his own.
So the opposition can still block his candidate.
He will have to choose a compromised candidate.
Otherwise, we'll be back in a political crisis again.
NPR's Ivan Watson speaking to us from Istanbul.
Thanks a lot, Ivan.
You're welcome, Jacki.
There's a dive bar in Brooklyn that's become the local watering hole for murderers and tyrants, adulterers and virgins, Don Juans and divas.
In fact, many of the great characters in opera show up in the backroom of Freddy's Bar.
That's where the opera company Opera on Tap performs a monthly concert for younger and drunker audiences that you might find at the Met.
NPR's Robert Smith raised a glass there this week.
If you spend some late-night hours hanging out in a bar, you'd probably met a girl like Carmen.
She's hot.
She's kind of cruel.
She's out for herself and her own interests.
She smokes?
Yeah, she - I think she drinks, she dances, all that good stuff.
Too bad Carmen's been trapped on an opera stage for the last 130 years.
Oh, but not on this night.
These days, the original party girl is shaking it in the bar just like she's Paris Hilton.
(Soundbite of ""Habanera"" aria)
(Soundbite of coughing)
(Soundbite of laughter)
(Singing in French)
You're welcome.
Well, the Political Junkie column, which was once a week, is now - they thought that the column was going too long at 3,000 words per column.
So now it's every day at 3,000 words.
It started Monday.
Over five people, I believe, have been reading it around the country, and yes...
We checked it out, and they're all your relatives.
Well, yes.
If those not related to Ken would like to see it, it's at npr.org.
But let's get on to that news from Georgia, Saxby Chambliss - well, almost won re-election.
He got 49.8.
Forty-nine point eight.
And this time around though, it wasn't even close.
Right.
It was 57 to 43.
Georgia, of course, is one of the few states that needs - you need a majority to win.
I think Vermont may be the only other state that you need a majority.
Louisiana, I think, too.
How's bayou?
OK.
Yeah, thanks.
But so - but in Georgia - so, he - that was basically World War III.
I mean, it was, they say it's a first salvo for the 2010 campaign, the beginning of the 2012 campaign.
If you think of all the presidential candidates who were down there, it was Mike Huckabee with Mitt Romney, with Sarah Palin, it was Ludacris, I think he's running for president, too.
Yeah.
But Ludacris was campaigning for Jim Martin, the Democratic candidate, as did Bill Clinton, as did Al Gore.
And it was really - you know, Barack Obama not being on the ballot apparently is what really hurt Jim Martin, even though Jim Martin outpolled Barack Obama in Georgia on November 4th.
But the black turnout was down.
Democratic turnout was - it seemed to be down.
Republican enthusiasm was really big, and Saxby Chambliss tried to make the argument, and made the argument, that one, they don't want a veto-proof or a filibuster-proof majority.
The Democrats, they don't want another rubber stamp for Barack Obama.
And the conservative Georgia, which had been reliably conservative except it was very close on November 4th, came through for him.
And Barack Obama did not go campaign in Georgia, though he did cut a campaign spot for -
And made - he made some robocalls as well.
OK.
He did.
Let's go back to Minnesota now.
How long does this recount take?
Well, it will be over December 16th.
Right now, they're counting all 2.9 million votes by hand.
Right now, incumbent Republican Norm Coleman leads Democratic challenger Al Franklin by 303 votes.
I mean, every one is being scrutinized and analyzed and fought over.
But there are several provisional ballots, disputed ballots, that will be decided upon on December 16th.
And so by December 19th, they will certify a winner.
So we have two more weeks of the Minnesota thing.
But what it means, of course, what happened in Georgia is that Democrats, the most they can get is 59.
They will not get the magic 60.
Although, you know, of course anybody, any Senate could switch over, you know, Susan Collins, Olympia Snowe could switch over to the Democrats.
Joe Lieberman could switch over the Republicans, a lot of things (unintelligible).
There are different issues.
These coalitions are hardly firm.
Exactly.

So, in any case, there are now, with a couple of Cabinet appointments, new governors in New Mexico - today, Bill Richardson was named to be Commerce secretary - and in Arizona, where Janet Napolitano will now come to Washington, D.C., to be the director of homeland security.
Right.
Well, Bill Richardson, it's obvious what he's trying to do.
He's obviously always wanted to the follow in the footsteps of Herbert Hoover.
Going from Commerce secretary to president is a long tradition.
